statement:
Continuous functions defined on compact subsets of ${\mathbb R}^n$ are
Riemann integrable.

Let $D\subset {\mathbb R}^n$ be a compact subset of ${\mathbb R}^n$ and
let $f\colon D\to {\mathbb R}$ be a continuous function. Since $f$ is
defined on a compact set, $f$ is uniformly continuous i.e. given
$\epsilon>0$ there exists $\delta>0$ such that
$|x-y|\le \delta \Rightarrow |f(x)-f(y)|\le \epsilon$. Let $R>0$ be
large enough so that $D\subset (-R,R)^n$ (such an $R$ exists because $D$
is bounded). Let $P$ be a polyrectangle such that
$D\subset \cup P \subset (-R,R)^n$ and such that every rectangle $R$ in
$P$ has diameter which is less then $\delta$. So one has
$\sup_R f(x)-\inf_R f(x) \le \epsilon$ and hence
$$S^*(f,P)-S_*(f,P)\le \epsilon \sum_{Q\in P} \mathrm{meas} (Q) \le \epsilon \mathrm{meas}(P) \le \epsilon \mathrm{meas}[-R,R]^n = \epsilon 2^n R^n.$$
Letting $\epsilon\to 0$ one concludes that $S^*(f)=S_*(f)$.
names: continuous functions of several variables are Riemann summable
